data.tagHTML: Punya karma is earned when our activities are good and comforting to others. The Sth√§n√§nga Sutra describes nine ways to acquire Punya, primarily through offering (D√§n) to deserving people (Sup√§tra) like Jain ascetics and people in need.

data.tagHTML: Jain scriptures describe eighteen kinds of activities that are the main sources of sin (P√§p). These should be avoided as they lead to suffering in this life and future lives. Click on each sin to learn more about it.

items.content: To injure or kill any of the ten vitalities (Pr√§n) of a living being through non-vigilance or ignorance. This includes physical, verbal, and mental violence.
To tell a lie. This includes spreading rumors, revealing secrets, writing false documents, or even speaking a truth that hurts others unnecessarily.
To take something without the owner's permission. This also includes tax evasion, adulteration, and using false weights and measures.
Engaging in sensuous enjoyment and pre- or extra-marital relationships. It arises from excessive sensual desire.
Accumulating more worldly objects than one needs. Greed is the root cause of this sin.
The first passion (Kash√§y). It destroys friendships and makes one unable to distinguish right from wrong. Should be overcome with forgiveness.
Ego, pride, or conceit. Thinking too much of oneself and looking down on others. It can be pride of family, knowledge, strength, etc.
To cheat or mislead others. A deceitful person is always restless and lacks peace of mind. The opposite is straightforwardness (Saralat√§).
The desire for more than one needs. It is the root of all other passions and sins. One should cultivate contentment instead.
Developing a strong liking or craving for worldly objects, people, or beliefs. It is one of the hardest passions to identify and conquer.
Aversion, enmity, or jealousy towards others. It is the other side of the coin to attachment (R√§g). Should be overcome with love and compassion.
Engaging in disputes and fights, often over trivial matters. It arises from frustration and anger.
Making false accusations against someone, often out of jealousy or to cover one's own faults.
Slandering someone or spreading rumors behind their back. It leads to unnecessary discord and quarrels.
Taking pleasure in sinful activities (Rati) and disliking religious or virtuous activities (Arati).
Finding fault in others and criticizing them with negative intent to put them down.
Telling a malicious lie with the specific intent to cheat someone. It is a combination of deceit and untruthfulness.
The most dangerous sin. Trusting a wrong god, wrong guru, or wrong religion. It is the root cause of all other sins.

data.tagHTML: The Four-Fold Combinations of Punya and P√§p
The bondage of new karma depends on our soul's reflections (Anubandh) while experiencing the fruits of past karma. This creates four combinations:

items.content: While enjoying the fruits of past Punya (e.g., wealth), one performs more righteous deeds, like charity. This is the best state.
While enjoying the fruits of past Punya, one becomes arrogant and indulges in non-virtuous activities. This is the most common state for worldly beings.
While suffering the fruits of past P√§p (e.g., poverty), one remains calm, accepts it as their own doing, and continues to live virtuously. This is a rare and noble state.
While suffering the fruits of past P√§p, one becomes bitter, blames others, and commits more sinful acts. This is the worst state, leading to a downward spiral.
